comment.author: 39191857@N05
comment._content: The range of expressions etc. are intriguing.  The only one who looks happy is the Bridesmaid on the left/right who has a decent smile on her face.  The bride looks apprehensive yet happy.  The groom looks grim in that outsized stiff celluloid collar that is probably irritating the devil out of him, the flower girl probably wants to be off playing "picky" somewhere and not in that outfit and the rest are just waiting to get at the grub.  Nice one Carol, good start to your week!

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: I think I hit the mother lode in the Irish Times from Saturday, 15th August 1903, not least by finding out that all three bridesmaids were called Violet!: "FASHIONABLE MARRIAGE The marriage between Mr. Cecil Thomas Atkinson, of 26 Herbert place, Dublin, second son of the Right Hon John Atkinson, Attorney-General for Ireland, and Miss Florence Taylor, eldest daughter of Mr. Godfrey Lovelace Taylor, of Grangeville, Fethard, Co. Wexford, took place on Thursday, the 6th inst., in the pretty parish church which adjoins the grounds of Mr. Taylor's residence. The service was performed by the Rev. Richard M. Kellett, M.A., assisted by Canon Cooper and the Rev. T. Fairley. The bride, who was given away by her father, was attired in a gown of Louisine satin, the skirt being trimmed with bandigued frills of accordion-pleated chiffon. The bodice had transparent neck and sleeves of rucked chiffon and a tucked satin wattee over rucked chiffon, finished with a Carrickmacross collar. She wore an embroidered tulle veil over a coronet of orange blossom, and the Court train was of rich ivory brocade. Her ornaments were an old miniature pendant and sapphire and diamond crescent, the gifts of the bridegroom. The bridesmaids were Miss Violet Taylor (sister of the bride), Miss Violet Barret Hamilton and Miss Violet Cunningham, and the bride's train was carried by two children, Miss Ethel Mary Taylor (sister of the bride) and Mis Eda Anketell Jones. The bridesmaids were dressed in white cordion-pleated soie-de-chine, inserted with cream-coloured lace, the coatees having deep lace collars. They carried bouquets of pink carnations and wore pearl and turquoise pendants, the gifts of the bridegroom. The train-bearers wore white silk frocks inserted with lace, with hats to match and wore gold heart-shaped pendants presented to them by the bridegroom. The best man was Mr. Hubert Atkinson, of the Connaught Rangers, brother of the bridegroom."
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 29809546@N00
comment._content:
Some highlights from the legal career of The Hon Cecil Atkinson, as reported in The (London) Times: 22nd July 1908 - Cork assizes. he is part of the team representing Hon. Alexis Burke Roche, who sued Sir Timothy O'Brien, of Lohort Castle for slander.
The case excited an extraordinary amount of public interest, and the court was crowded. The alleged slander was uttered at a meeting of Duhallow Fowhounds, on March 7 last, when the plaintiff alleges the defendant, in the presence of members of the hunt, characterized him as "a liar, a thief, and a swindler who, to his knowledge, had been living by swindling for 20 years".
28th October 1908 - the same case, having been terminated at Cork due to alleged interference by the defendant with one of the jurors, is heard at Dublin. Mr Cecil Atkinson requests a adjournment of one week. 1st April 1913 - He appears on behalf of a Mrs Russel who had left husband, a barrister, on account of his "violence and immoral conduct ... Russel had threatened the lives of the children if they were taken from him". 13th Januaury 1913 He is part of the team representing the police at the Viceregal Commission "which is inquiring into the riots that occurred in Dublin in AUgust" 10th Sptember 1915 - He is listed (as Hon. Cecil Atkinson, K.C.) as a Distinguished Patron of the newly-formed Anti-German League. 14th December 1915
NEW INDIAN HIGH COURT JUDGESHIP FOR IRISH K.C. Whe understand that the Hon. Cecil T Atkinson, K.C., has been selected as a Puisne Judge of the newly-formed High COurt of Behar and Orissa, and that an official announcement awaits the completion of prelimenary arrangements in India for formal proclamation of the court. ... Mr Atkinson is the eldest son Of Lord Atkinson, Lord of Appeal in Ordinary. He was called to the Irish Bar in Trinity Term, 1901, and took silk two years later
He died on 20th November 1919 in India. His family gravestone

comment.author: 29809546@N00
comment._content: Hubert Atkinson barely scraped into Sandhurst  with 5409 marks in the competitive entrance exam held at the end of 1900 (the top of the list got 9546 and the lowest successful mark was 5186), but  attained the rank of  Lieutenant Colonel. In June 1932  Lieutenant Colonel the Hon Hubert Atkinson is listed as an attendee of  the Connaught Rangers annual regimental dinner at the Victoria Hotel.

comment.author: 29809546@N00
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/nlireland] Mostly deaths here I'm afraid. I imagined it was some sort of tropical fever which brought about Cecil's untimely demise, but NO! Read on.. In the obituary on 14th March 1932 of Lord Atkinson (John Atkinson 1844-1932), the father of Cecil Thomas and Hubert Rowan (and of Edward and Hector), The London Times says
He married in 1873 Rowena, daughter of Richard Chute, MD, of Tralee; she was well known in Dublin society, especially for her caustic wit. She died in 1911, and of the four sons of the marriage only the youngest, Lieutenant-Colonel Hubert Rowan Atkinson, survives. The eldest, Edward Chute, died in 1906; the third, Captain Hector John Anderson, died in 1917; and the second, Cecil Thomas, a Judge of the High Court at Patna, was killed on the railway in India in 1919.
So back to 1919. A brief note on 22nd November states
Lord Atkinson, a Lord of Appeal in Ordinary, received yesterday news from the India Office that his elder son, Mr Cecil Thomas Atkinson KC, an Indian Judge, had been killed in a railway accident in India while on his way from Bombay to Patna.
And on 28th November a bit more detail:
INDIAN JUDGE'S DEATH ALLAHABAD Nov 19 (delayed) - The body of Mr Justice Atkinson, of the Patna High Court, has been found on a railway line at Sutna. It appears that the judge was travelling to Bankipur, a suburb of Patna. The guard noticed on the journey that the door of a lavatory was open, and on a search being made the body was discovered. The funeral took place here yesterday afternoon. Mr Justice Atkinson only arrived from England last week.
So did he fall out of the train? We need an expert on the layout of railway carriages in West Bengal 1910-1920. As for 'A Passage to India', according to the wikipedia entry for Bankipore/Bankipur It is believed that E. M. Forster based the city of Chandrapore in his novel A Passage to India on this town., so you were spot on there, Carol. I haven't found out what eventually happened to Hubert, but I have found that if you search for 'Hubert Rowan Atkinson' you get a lot of stuff about Mr Bean.

comment.author: 29809546@N00
comment._content: Some judgments made by Mr Justice Atkinson in the High Court at Patna. The last one was pronounced on 23rd July 1919, so presumably he went on home leave after that to return in November.

comment.author: 29809546@N00
comment._content:
The opening of the High Court at Patna in 1916 was a grand affair, as befitting its importance. This description was found on the most unlikely website.
Thus the ancient city of Pataliputra had a High Court of its own in 1916 with Sir Edward Maynard Des Champs Chamier, Kt. Barrister-at-Law as its first Chief Justice and Sarvashri Saiyid Sharfuddin, Barrister-at-Law, Edmund Pelly Chapman, I.C.S., Basant Kumar Mullick, I.C.S., Francis, Reginald Roe, I.C.S, Cecil Atkinson, barrister-at-Law and Jwala Prasad, B.A., LL.B., as Puisne Judges. ... The High Court actually commenced work from the 1st March, 1916. On that day the Hon’ble Judges wore full court dress. They were robed in red gowns, wigs, black knee breeches, black silk stockings and buckled patent leather shoes. Exactly at 10.35 the Judges entered the Chief Justice’s Court room and took their seats on red morocco stuffed armless chairs on the dais. The Registrar of the Court, the Commissioner of the Division, the Commissioner of Excise and Registration and some local high officials took their seat on the dais behind the Judges. The Judges were welcomed on behalf of the Bar by Maulana Mazharul Haq, Barrister-at-Law.
I can't imagine that such an auspicious occasion was allowed to pass without it being recorded for posterity by the Patna equivalent of A.H. Poole, and that somewhere in the vaults of the NLI (National Library of India) there isn't a dusty glass plate negative showing the judges and high local officials in all their finery ... Patna High Court today. Not quite as grand as I imagined, but the architect's plans were probably mistakenly swapped for somewhere in Ireland.

comment.author: 24038696@N07
comment._content: These photos are fascinating in thier own right, but the detective work that people bring to the comments are astonishing!!!  It seems a bit odd to describe finding ta body in the lavatory as a "train accident" although perhaps a sudden jarring stop or motion by the train had caused him a fatal blow to the head?

comment.author: 29809546@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/laurala2008] Certainly some odd aspects to the death.  The account in the SIngapore Free Press is a little more detailed. His absence was noticed at Mogulserai, but his body was found 150 miles back down the track at Sutna. But it also says he had  a servant with him on the journey. Why was it a railway official and not the servant who raised the alarm? I wondered if there had been an inquest or inquiry into his death but I couldn't find anything.

comment.author: 29809546@N00
comment._content: Meanwhile in 1923 the Hon Mrs. Cecil Atkinson attended the last Court of the season at Buckingham palace (along with several thousand others), and in 1932 attended the wedding of Mr Graham Lawrie Mackeson, Irish Guards, and Miss Geraldine Pamela Violet Sandbach.

comment._content: I am so thrilled to find this photograph.  The dapper best man, Hubert Rowan Atkinson, was the father of my Uncle Desmond, who married my father's sister Diana Lipscomb.  If anyone can give me any more information about the family, I would be hugely grateful.  Uncle Desmond is now dead and Aunt Diana, at 97, is too ill to remember.
